choices.text: They can be absorbed in conditions associated with fat malabsorption
They are transported in blood freely
Toxicity may occur as a result of excess intake

questions.text: True regarding Common properties of lipid soluble vitamins is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Due to their storage capability, toxicity can result from excessive intake of fat-soluble vitamins.
  • For instance, hypervitaminosis A and D can result from overconsumption of supplements or fortified foods.
  • The lipid-soluble vitamins are hydrophobic compounds that can be absorbed efficiently only when there is normal fat absorption. Like other lipids, they are transported in the blood in lipoproteins or attached to specific binding proteins. (Other options ruled out)
  • As well as dietary inadequacy, conditions affecting the digestion and absorption of the lipid-soluble vitamins, such as a very-low-fat diet, steatorrhea, and disorders of the biliary system, intestinal absorption disorders can all lead to deficiency syndromes, including:
    • Night blindness and xerophthalmia (vitamin A)
    • Rickets in young children and osteomalacia in adults (vitamin D)
    • Neurologic disorders and hemolytic anaemia of the newborn (vitamin E)
    • Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (vitamin K).

Key takeaways:

Vitamins can be divided into two categories:

  • Fat-soluble:
    • Vitamin A
    • Vitamin D
    • Vitamin E
    • Vitamin K
  • Water soluble:
    • Vitamin B
    • Vitamin C

questions.text: Vitamin A functions as a prosthetic group in cones of the eye as.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin A functions as retinaldehyde, the prosthetic group of the rods and cones, as Rhodopsin in the rods and Iodopsin in the cones in the retina.

Vitamin A:

  • Each cone cell in the retina is specialised to detect one of three primary colours: blue, green, or red. This specialisation allows for colour vision.
  • Each cone cell contains a single type of opsin pigment that determines its sensitivity to a specific wavelength of light, corresponding to one of the primary colours.
  • Vitamin A deficiency is the most important preventable cause of blindness.
  • The earliest sign of deficiency is loss of sensitivity to green light,followed by impairment in adapting to dim light, night blindness and eventually inability to see in the dark.
  • In vitamin A deficiency, both time and ability to adapt in the dark are poor. Vitamin A is essential for the synthesis of rhodopsin in rod cells, which are responsible for vision in low-light conditions.
  • Prolonged deficiency leads to xerophthalmia, keratinisation of the cornea and eventually blindness.

Explanation of other options:

Rhodopsin(Option A): Vitamin A functions as a prosthetic group of the rods as Rhodopsin.

Conopsin(Option B): It is a photopigment, a light-sensitive protein and when bound to retinal, becomes Iodopsin.

choices.text: Any one cone has only one type of Color vision i.e. Blue, green or red
Any one cone has only one type of opsin pigment
Ability to adapt in darkness is decreased in Vitamin A deficiency is decreased
Time taken to adapt in the dark is decreased in Vitamin A deficiency

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In vitamin A deficiency, the time taken to adapt to darkness is increased, not decreased. This is due to impaired regeneration of rhodopsin in rod cells, leading to prolonged dark adaptation. So, the above D statement is wrong.

Explanation of other options:

Option A: Each cone cell in the retina is specialised to detect one of three primary colours: blue, green, or red. This specialisation allows for colour vision.

Option B: Each cone cell contains a single type of opsin pigment that determines its sensitivity to a specific wavelength of light, corresponding to one of the primary colours

Option C: In vitamin A deficiency, both time and ability to adapt in the dark are poor. Vitamin A is essential for the synthesis of rhodopsin in rod cells, which are responsible for vision in low-light conditions. A deficiency in vitamin A impairs rhodopsin regeneration, leading to delayed or impaired dark adaptation, commonly known as night blindness.

questions.text: The deficiency of Vitamin A impairs the function of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin A has a role in gene expression and tissue differentiation.

In this regard, Vitamin A forms two receptors:

  • Retinoic acid receptors(RARs): these bind all-trans retinoic acid and
  • Retinoid X receptors(RXRs): these bind all-cis retinoic acid. These receptors also play an additional role in forming Dimers to help form receptors for Vitamin D and Thyroid hormones, causing the deficiency of Vitamin A to impair Vitamin D and thyroid hormone functions.

RXR:

  • RXR dimers are used for receptor formation, but deficiency causes the formation of inactive dimers.
  • They, in turn, bind to occupied Vit. D and thyroid hormone to cause their repression, thus causing a negative role in their functions, having a more severe effect than simple deficiency.

Key takeaways:

  • Retinoic acid is the compound that is involved in gene expression and tissue differentiation.
  • The retina is involved in the visual cycle. The absorption of light by rhodopsin causes isomerisation of 11-cis retinal to 11 trans retinal, which leads to the generation of a nerve impulse. Both cis retinal and trans retinal have no role in the regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation.
  • Retinol is vitamin A alcohol, with no role in the regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation.

choices.text: Hepatomegaly due to hyperactivation of Stella cells present in the space of Disse
Headache and ataxia due to decreased cerebrospinal fluid

questions.text: The Following is not a symptom of Vitamin. A toxicity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Headache and Ataxia are caused by vitamin A toxicity due to increased cerebrospinal fluid and not decreased, so the D option is incorrect.
  • There is only a limited capacity to metabolise vitamin A, and excessive intakes lead to accumulation beyond the capacity of intracellular binding proteins. Unbound vitamin A causes membrane lysis and tissue damage.

Vitamin A toxicity leads to:

  • Headache and increased intracranial pressure (pseudotumor cerebri).
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Drowsiness, dizziness, irritability
  • Blurred or double vision, visual disturbances.
  • Hair changes (alopecia), eyebrow loss, and desquamation of skin. (Option C ruled out.)
  • Hepatomegaly and liver damage. (Option A ruled out.)
  • Bone pain, cortical hyperostosis, arthralgia, fractures.
  • Hypercalcemia (Option B ruled out)
  • Bulging fontanelle, craniotabes.
  • Poor weight gain or failure to thrive (children).
  • Jaundice or yellowed skin

Key takeaways:

Vitamin A teratogenicity:

  • A syndrome of severe congenital malformations may occur in infants of mothers who have consumed therapeutic doses (0.5-1.5 mg/kg) of oral 13-cis-retinoic acid, generally taken for the treatment of acne or cancer, during the 1st trimester of pregnancy
  • These malformations result in a high incidence (>20%) of spontaneous abortions and birth defects, including characteristic craniofacial abnormalities.
  • Excessive intake of carotenoids is not associated with toxicity but can cause yellow colouration of the skin (carotenodermia) and serum (carotenemia) that disappears when intake is reduced. ced

questions.text: The Active form of Vitamin. D is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The active form of Vitamin. D is 1, 25 (OH)2 Vit. D is also called Calcitriol.
  • Cholecalciferol, either synthesised in the skin or from food, undergoes two hydroxylations to yield the active metabolite, 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D or calcitriol.
  • Ergocalciferol from fortified foods undergoes similar hydroxylation to yield calcitriol.
  • In the liver, cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to form the 25-hydroxy derivative, calcidiol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D-binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.
  • In the kidney, calcidiol undergoes either 1-hydroxylation to yield the active metabolite 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D (calcitriol) or 24-hydroxylation to yield a probably inactive metabolite, 24,25-dihydroxy vitamin D (24-hydroxy calcidiol).

Vitamin D functions and deficiency:

  • Vitamin D is not strictly a vitamin since it can be synthesised in the skin, and in most conditions, this is the major source of the vitamin. Only when sunlight exposure is inadequate, a dietary source is required.
  • Its main function is in the regulation of calcium absorption and homeostasis. Most of its actions are mediated by way of nuclear receptors that regulate gene expression. It also has a role in regulating cell proliferation and differentiation.
  • There is evidence that intakes considerably higher than are required to maintain calcium homeostasis reduce the risk of insulin resistance, obesity, and the metabolic syndrome, as well as various cancers.
  • Deficiency, leading to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, is a problem in northern latitudes, where sunlight exposure is inadequate.e

Vitamin D toxicity:

  • Excess Vit. D is the most toxic vitamin when taken in excess as it causes abnormal calcification of soft tissues, contraction of blood vessels and high blood pressure.
  • Although excess dietary vitamin D is toxic, excessive exposure to sunlight does not lead to vitamin D poisoning, because there is a limited capacity to form the precursor, 7-dehydrocholesterol, and prolonged exposure of previtamin D to sunlight leads to formation of inactive compounds.

Explanation:

  • The primary role of vitamin D is to control calcium homeostasis in the body.
  • Vitamin D metabolism is regulated by factors that respond to the plasma concentrations of calcium and phosphate.
  • Calcitriol and Calcium are the two main regulators of Vitamin D.

Role of Calcitriol: Calcitriol (the active form of vitamin D) is a key player in this regulation.

  • When there is an excess of calcitriol (active vitamin D) in the body, it acts to reduce its synthesis.
  • Calcitriol induces the enzyme 24-hydroxylase, which breaks down active vitamin D.
  • Calcitriol represses the enzyme 1-hydroxylase, which is responsible for the synthesis of active vitamin D in the kidney.

Calcium and Phosphate Affecting Vitamin D Activity:

  • When the concentration of calcium in the blood decreases, it triggers the activation of vitamin D to increase calcium absorption in the intestines.
  • Reduced phosphate levels in the blood also contribute to the activation of vitamin D, aiding in calcium absorption.
  • The primary and central function of vitamin D is to maintain the concentration of calcium in the bloodstream, ensuring calcium homeostasis.

Functions of Vitamin D:

Maintaining the plasma calcium concentration:

  • It increases intestinal absorption of calcium
  • It reduces excretion of calcium(by stimulating reabsorption in the distal renal tubules).
  • And it mobilises bone mineral.

Other functions:

  • Calcitriol is involved in insulin secretion.
  • Synthesis and secretion of parathyroid and thyroid hormones.
  • Immune function: inhibition of production of interleukin by activated T-lymphocytes and of immunoglobulin by activated B-lymphocytes, differentiation of monocyte precursor cells, and modulation of cell proliferation.

Vitamin D Toxicity:

  • Excess Vit. D is the most toxic vitamin when taken in excess, as it causes abnormal calcification of soft tissues, which can lead to contraction of blood vessels and high blood pressure.
  • Although excess dietary vitamin D is toxic, excessive exposure to sunlight does not lead to vitamin D poisoning, because there is a limited capacity to form the precursor, 7-dehydrocholesterol, and prolonged exposure of previtamin D to sunlight leads to the formation of inactive compounds.

questions.text: Vit. E is the major antioxidant in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • E is a chain-breaking, free radical-trapping antioxidant present in cell membranes and plasma lipoproteins that acts by reacting with the lipid peroxide radicals formed by peroxidation of polyunsaturated fatty acids. It traps the free radicals, forming inactive complexes, thus reducing the oxidative stress.
  • C reduces the tocopheroxyl radical back to tocopherol, thus releasing Vitamin E. L-α-tocopherol is inactive. D-α-tocopherol is the most active. Synthetic D-α-tocopherol does not have the same biologic potency as the naturally occurring compound.
  • The resultant stable monodehydroascorbate radical then undergoes enzymic or non-enzymic reaction to yield ascorbate and dehydroascorbate, neither of which is a radical.
  • Vitamin C and beta carotene also act as antioxidants, but are less abundant in the plasma membrane.
  • Premature infants are born with inadequate reserves of vitamin E. The erythrocyte membranes are abnormally fragile as a result of lipid peroxidation, leading to hemolytic anaemia.
  • Thus, Vit E deficiency leads to hemolytic anaemia due to lipid peroxidation, leading to fragile RBC membranes.
  • Vitamin E deficiency in humans, leading to nerve and muscle membrane damage, may lead to neurological dysfunction

Causes of Vitamin E deficiency:

  • Severe fat malabsorption
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Chronic liver disease.
  • Dietary deficiency of Vit. E in human beings is very rare and generally not associated with Vitamin. E deficiency.

Key takeaways:

  • Ascorbate, uric acid, and a variety of polyphenols derived from plant foods act aswater-solubleradical-trapping antioxidants, forming relatively stable radicals that persist long enough to undergo reaction to nonradical products.
  • Ubiquinone and carotenes similarly act as lipid-soluble radical-trapping antioxidants in membranes and plasma lipoproteins.

questions.text: Compounds that have the biological activity of Vitamin K are all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Quinolone is an antibiotic and has no relation to vitamin K.

Three compounds have the biological activity of vitamin K:

  • Phylloquinone, the normal dietary source, is found in green vegetables. (Option nA ruled out)
  • Menaquinones, synthesised by intestinal bacteria with differing lengths of side chain, are absorbed to some extent, but it is not clear to what extent they are biologically active. (Option B ruled out.t)
  • Menadione and menadiol diacetate, synthetic compounds that can be metabolised to phylloquinone. (Option C ruled out.).

Cofactor activity of vitamin K:

  • Vitamin K is the cofactor for the carboxylation of glutamate residues in the postsynthetic modification of proteins to form the unusual amino acid γ-carboxygutamate (GLA).
  • Initially, vitamin K hyroquinone is oxidised to the epoxide, which activates a glutamate residue in the protein substrate to form a carbanion, which reacts nonenzymatically with carbon dioxide to form γ-carboxygutamate.
  • Thus, Vitamin K works by a Carboxylation mechanism for the formation of important proteins to form clotting factors.
  • Several proteins undergo the same vitamin K-dependent carboxylation of glutamate to γ-carboxyglutamate, which include:
    • Osteocalcin
    • Protein C and S
    • Matrix Gla protein in bone
    • Nephrocalcin in the kidney and
    • Growth arrest-specific gene Gas6, which is involved in both the regulation of differentiation and development in the nervous system and the control of apoptosis in other tissues.
  • All of these y-carboxyglutamate-containing proteins bind calcium, which causes a conformational change so that they interact with membrane phospholipids.

questions.text: High dose Vit. K is an antidote for poisoning by which drug?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vit K is reduced to form the active compound by both warfarin-sensitive and warfarin-insensitive enzymes.
  • In the presence of warfarin, Vit. K epoxied cannot be reduced as the warfarin-sensitive enzyme is blocked, and the Vit. K, which then accumulates, is excreted by the body.
  • If enough Vitamin K is provided, it can be metabolised(reduction reaction) into its active form by the warfarin-insensitive enzyme, and thus, carboxylation can continue.
  • Thus, high-dose Vitamin. K can be used as an antidote for warfarin overdose.

Explanation of other options:

Heparin(Option B): The antidote for Heparin is Protamine sulfate.

Aspirin(Option C): There is no antidote for aspirin poisoning; it's only supportive management and may involve treatment of dehydration, hyperthermia, hypokalemia and convulsions.

Clopidogrel(Option D): Overdosing of clopidogrel can be treated by platelet transfusion.

choices.text: Due to intestine bacteria which metabolise vit. K
Low levels of Vitamin K in the breast milk
Under functioning of Vitamin K activating enzyme

questions.text: Newborns are prone to develop Vitamin K deficiency due to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Newborns have sterile intestines and initially lack the bacteria that synthesise vitamin K.(Option A)
  • Human milk provides only about one-fifth of the daily requirement for vitamin K to newborns. (Option B)
  • Newborns may have immature liver function, including reduced activity of enzymes necessary to activate Vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. (Option C)
  • This is the reason that newborns are prone to developing Vitamin K deficiency, which is one of the causes of hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.
  • It is recommended that all newborns receive a single intramuscular dose of vitamin K as prophylaxis against hemorrhagic disease.

choices.text: Deficiency of a single vitamin of the B complex is rare
Required in large quantities for a variety of biochemical functions
Generally cannot be synthesized by the body and must be supplied in the diet
Vitamin is a misnomer term, as all vitamins are not amine in nature

questions.text: : Which of the following statements is wrong about vitamins?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vitamins are a group of organic nutrients, required in small quantities for a variety of biochemical functions, and are not required in very large amounts.
  • Deficiency of a single vitamin of the B complex is rare since poor diets are most often associated with multiple deficiency states. (Option A ruled out.)
  • Generally, Vitamins cannot be synthesised by the body and therefore must be supplied in the diet. (Option C ruled out.)
  • Vitamins are a diverse group of chemical molecules; all are chemically non-amino. But the term vitamin, however, is continued without the final letter 'e'. So, the term vitamine (vital amine) is considered a misnomer. (Option D ruled out.)

choices.text: The synthesis of retinol binding protein is decreased
The synthesis of retinol binding protein is increased
Retinol binding protein is positive acute phase proteins

questions.text: During inflammatory response, circulating form of vitamin A is reduced because:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The circulating form of Vitamin A is reduced during inflammation because the synthesis of retinol binding protein is decreased.

During the inflammatory process:

  • Those plasma proteins whose levels are changed in plasma (> 25%) during inflammation (as a result of any infection, injury, malignancy, surgery, etc) are known as Acute Phase Proteins or Acute Phase Reactants.
  • Plasma proteins whose levels increase in inflammation, known as Positive acute-phase proteins. Examples are α1-antitypsin, α2-macroglobulin, C-reactive protein, Complement proteins, Ceruloplasmin, Haptoglobin, Ferritin, Fibrinogen, Mannose binding proteins etc.,
  • Plasma proteins whose levels decrease in inflammation, known as Negative Acute Phase Proteins. Examples are Albumin, Prealbumin (Transthyretin), Transferrin, and Retinol binding proteins. (Option C ruled out.)
  • Retinol binding protein is required to transport the vitamin in the bloodstream.
  • The synthesis of retinol-binding protein is reduced in response to infection (as it is a negative acute phase protein), so decreasing the circulating concentration of the vitamin and further impairing immune responses. (Option B ruled out.)

choices.text: Vitamin D metabolism is regulated by calcium homeostasis
In temperate climates, the plasma concentration of vitamin D is highest at the end of summer and lowest at the end of winter.
In temperate climates, the plasma concentration of vitamin D is lowest at the end of summer and highest at the end of winter.

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding vitamin D, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In temperate climates, the plasma concentration of vitamin D exhibits a clear seasonal variation, being highest at the end of summer and lowest at the end of winter. This pattern corresponds with the intensity of solar UVB radiation, which is strongest in summer and weakest in winter, affecting the skin's ability to synthesise vitamin D.
  • In temperate climates, the plasma concentration of vitamin D is not lowest at the end of summer and not highest at the end of winter.

Explanation of other options:

Option A & B:

  • Vitamin D metabolism is both regulated by and regulates calcium homeostasis
  • The main function of vitamin D is in the control of calcium homeostasis. And turn, vitamin D metabolism is regulated by factors that respond to plasma concentrations of calcium and phosphate.
  • Calcitriol acts to reduce its synthesis by inducing the 24-hydroxylase and repressing the 1-hydroxylase in the kidney.
  • The principal function of vitamin D is to maintain the plasma calcium concentration. Calcitriol achieves this in three ways: it increases intestinal absorption of calcium; it reduces excretion of calcium (by stimulating reabsorption in the distal renal tubules); and it mobilises bone mineral.

Option C: In temperate climates, the plasma concentration of vitamin D is highest at the end of summer and lowest at the end of winter. Beyond latitudes about 40° north or south, there is very little ultraviolet radiation of the appropriate wavelength in winter.

questions.text: A 52 years old male have history of bone pain and repeated fracture. He is suffering from chronic renal failure. On examination, following abnormality is observed. A patient is likely to be suffering from deficiency of which of the following compound?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above picture represents Bow legs, also known as Genu Varum. The patient with chronic renal failure, bone pain, and repeated fractures is likely suffering from a deficiency of calcitriol.
  • Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D, which is synthesised in the kidneys. In patients with chronic renal failure, the kidneys may not be able to convert vitamin D into its active form (calcitriol) effectively.
  • Calcitriol plays a crucial role in calcium homeostasis, bone health, and the absorption of calcium from the gastrointestinal tract.
  • A deficiency of calcitriol can lead to impaired calcium absorption and metabolism, resulting in bone pain and increased susceptibility to fractures.

Explanation of other options:

Ascorbic acid(Option A): It can cause scurvy, characterised by symptoms such as bleeding gums and skin issues, but it is not typically associated with bone pain and fractures.

Retinoic acid(Option B): It is a derivative of vitamin A and is not commonly associated with the symptoms described.

Folic acid(Option C): Its deficiency can lead to anaemia and other symptoms, but it is not typically associated with bone pain and fractures.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presented with abdominal pain & jaundice. Ultrasound abdomen shows a stone in the biliary tract. Which of the following vitamin injections should be given before doing any surgical procedure on this patient to avoid excess bleeding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of obstructive jaundice due to a biliary tract stone. Due to the absence of bile, lipid and lipid-soluble vitamins are not absorbed properly. Hence, it leads to a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (Vitamin A, D, E, K).
  • This patient is prone to Vitamin K deficiency.
  • Vitamin K is required for the clotting of blood. Vitamin injection should be given before doing any surgical procedure on this patient to avoid excess bleeding.

Sweet clover disease:

  • Vitamin K was discovered as a result of investigations into the cause of a bleeding disorder, sweet clover (haemorrhagic) disease of cattle and chickens fed on a fat-free diet.
  • The missing factor in the diet of the chickens was vitamin K, while the cattle feed contained dicumarol, an antagonist of vitamin K.

Explanation of other options:

Vitamin D(Option A): Vitamin D is fat fat-soluble vitamin. Its deficiency may be seen in this patient, but no role in clotting.

Vitamin C(Option C): Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. Its absorption is not impaired in fat malabsorption. Although vitamin C deficiency can lead to bleeding due to fragile vessels, due to improper formation of collagen.

Vitamin B12(Option D): Vitamin B12 is a water-soluble vitamin. Its absorption is not impaired in fat malabsorption.

questions.text: All of the following compounds are structural analogue of Vitamin K and inhibits Vitamin K activity, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Menadione (Vitamin K3) is a synthetic compound that can be metabolised to phylloquinone, so it has vitamin K activity.
  • Warfarin, Dicumarol, and Coumarin are structural analogues of Vitamin K and inhibit Vitamin K activity (act as Vitamin K Antagonists). These are commonly used to reduce blood clotting in patients with a high risk of thromboembolism. (Other options ruled out)
  • They competitively inhibit enzyme Epoxide reductase & Quinone reductase (Vit K reductase)
  • Indication of use:Prophylaxis & treatment of venous thromboembolism (deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism), Prophylaxis and treatment of Atrial fibrillation, Valvular stenosis, Heart valve replacement, etc..,
  • Use of Warfarin during pregnancy can lead to foetal bone abnormalities (foetal warfarin syndrome)
